job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Oakland, CA
pros:
-Great co-workers
-Good mission
-Multiple avenues of career advancement at the ready
-Competitive perks (pension, lots of vacation days, health insurance)
cons:
-Under managed. Onboarding is quite bumpy
-Lots of self-learning (very limited organized training) 
-Slow to promote

review_title: Physicians and staff are amazing, management is running this place into the ground
pros: Collaborative environment across all clinical disciplines, very approachable physicians who respect different clinical skills sets and value opinions. Staff and people feel like family and are very supportive and kind.
cons: Management and upper management continue to cut a lot of resources and have very poor understanding of what clinicians actually do. Management unwilling/unaware of how to allocate resources appropriately or solve departmental problems. Lots of rigidity and inflexibility in management across multiple levels, and management very resistant to actionable changes that would improve the quality of work environment for employees and better work/life balance. Exponentially increasing, chronic under-staffing issues and regular long days leading to consistent burnout with no support from management. Management does not know how to effectively train staff and staff in our department are often asked to see patients without adequate training because of always scrambling for patient care coverage. Rigid manager approach has led to alienation of the most senior and skilled clinicians. No value on employee longevity or staff retention. Management thinks staff are expendable and treat them as such without understanding how difficult certain clinical skill sets really are to replace. No caring about work/life balance. Managers would rather over-work employees to the point of burn out instead of implement solutions to retain staff.

review_title: Used to be proud to work here.
job_title: Staff RN II in Oakland, CA
pros: It was great to work at an organization committed to serve all members of a the community. Great interdisciplinary team work when we were an independent hospital. UCSF took over Children's and it has been difficult to bear witness to functional decline of the organization.
cons: UCSF has abandoned the values of Children's Hospital Oakland.

job_title: Clinical Social Worker in Oakland, CA
pros: Union position, benefits, decent pay, talented staff, management is open to feedback, etc.
cons: Slow processes from some parts of the organization, bureaucracy, unnecessary trainings, etc.

pros: good benefit for employee and family
cons: limited grow opportunity. low salary compared to west bay

review_title: A Place That Tries Their Best
pros: Friendly people and a tight knit community
cons: Organization can be lacking and hospital operations are not always the smoothest

review_title: Understaffed, no benefits, hardly on your own unit
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Oakland, CA
pros: Good pay, some nice people
cons: Understaffed, hardly any training so if you have no experience then you prob won't get hired here. They also like to hire more people for, what they called 'short hours' which does not offer benefits. Also a lot of construction happening. Manager seems unpleasantly negative at times

pros: Good Culture Good Community Care
cons: Bay is expensive, even though company pays well.

pros: As an organization it benefits from the affiliation with UCSF, but still can be independent in spirit. The work in the community as a safety-net hospital is well-respected and extremely important regional resource. It will keep you working here over and over again. There are some genuinely inspirational people at all levels who work here.
cons: Still struggling with its identity after the UCSF affiliation which began in 2015ish. There has been, and continues to be, a lot of transition pains. Fair amount of transition in leadership and tight budgets (both due to healthcare industry and the safety-net role the hospital plays in the community). Each department has been affected differently by the change - some are thriving and some are struggling. If you are interviewing, it is really important to ask questions about how the affiliation with UCSF has affected the unit you are working with.

review_title: I used to really like working here
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Oakland, CA
pros: Great pay and benefits. Union.
cons: Lack of supplies. Lack of support from management. Lack of morale on the unit and no sense of team. Short staffed. Sicker patients. No incentive to keep nurses on the unit. High turnover on the unit. No recognition from upper administration. There is no advocacy for nursing staff. We are just dumped on.

job_title: Pediatric Echo Sonographer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Extremely competitive pay. Very active union. Friendly staff
cons: Not respected as much as UCSF main campus. Since Children’s Hospital of Oakland was purchased by UCSF, we do not get as many perks or as much of a budget as the main campus does.

pros: Diverse. Provides care to underserved community. Great teamwork. Awesome manager.
cons: Not the best coordinator support. Lack of resources at times. Understaffed.

pros:
-incredible teamwork and team ethics
-good management and leadership
cons: -Poor coverage during PTO or when coworkesrs are out sick

review_title: Front line teams doing their best to weather the worsening storm
pros: Front line staff (nurses, physicians, therapists, patient care assistants, ward clerks, EVS, nutrition, dietary services, etc.) are some of the best people you will ever work with. They care about the mission, and they care about each other.
cons: Supervisors, most (not all) management, administration are highly fractured, unchecked in corruption and narcissism, and not doing their part to provide effective leadership. The organization is a slowly sinking ship in a storm. No career growth beyond RN II. Communication is poor. Unhealthy working environment with a culture that encourages favoritism, bullying, and working overtime after clocking out.

pros: Great company with great benefits. There is a lot of independence and doesn’t feel micromanaged environment. Very fast paced.
cons: No cons that I have noticed

job_title: Registered Nurse PICU in Oakland, CA
pros: diversity, unity, union nursing, exceptional pay, great benefits. awesome group of people on the inside.
cons: parking can be expensive unless you park on the street....

pros: Work here for the mission.
cons: The work culture is toxic, comes from the top down.

review_title: Good culture, but lacking health and wellbeing support for residents

-Many care coordination/ discharge planning, social work, and administrative tasks fall on residents, which take away from educational time and medical care of patients

pros: Community based, tight work crews

pros: Caring management, excellent benefits. Cutting edge technology.

pros: Its great to work here
cons: All is great excellent wonderful

review_title: Takeover by UCSF has changed this place dramatically
pros: A lot of people are very kind, very dedicated, very hard-working. Any children's hospital is the sweetheart of a community, right? All the staff are great, and the administrators...well keeping budgets lean is their mandate.
cons: The merger has also been called a hostile take over because when it looks and quacks like a duck...... Huge exodus of very good, dedicated people since UCSF started making all the calls and implementing budget-starvation. If they wanted to wipe out institutional memory they've largely succeeded.

review_title: Understaffed and lots of budget cuts

review_title: Experience at CHO depends on which lab you're in.

pros: Benefits are good. The Kaiser option for healthcare is zero $ for the employee. Great to have a union job.

cons: Pay not at up to par with other hospitals.

job_title: Registered Nurse in San Francisco, CA

review_title: Outpatient Pharmacy (not inpatient) needs better management, but has great flexible scheduling.
job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Oakland, CA
pros:
-Some days are busier than others.
-You can check your cellphone in the middle of work.
-1 hour lunch break
-incredibly flexible scheduling. Very easy to get a day off.
-Learn basic Spanish from many of the people there. If you are a technician, you will quickly pick up how to read Spanish labels, even if you don't know spanish. 
-there's a cafeteria upstairs, and the location is near many eateries
-Many customers are regulars here, and are often very nice and friendly. Occasionally you will have a bad customer, but the majority is full of happy, patient people.
cons:
-Technology is limited. Everything is compounded by hand, hand counted, etc.
-incredibly small work area. You'll constantly be bumping into people in this place.
-Some coworkers are very hostile. Be careful what you say.
-Incredibly poor management. Punishment for poor behavior is sparse (if any), and so people take advantage of this all the time.

review_title: Was a great place to work and the children were the top priority
pros: Helping children who sick or scared feel better was the most rewarding experience in my life.  The greatest people of the highest integrity I have ever worked with in my lifetime.  The kids received the best care from a great staff.
cons: New management has destroyed the moral of the staff.  The takeover by UCSF, bringing in their way of doing things, has led to paperwork and procedure over patient care.  I saw people retire who had been at Children's Hospital 35 or 40 years.  Now the best people have left bringing new employees who take a break or disappear when patients need care.  Breaks my heart what has transpired.

pros: Great benefits (not as good recently though, I heard) and flexible working conditions.  The people that work there are pretty great, mostly - friendly and have good senses of humor.  Plus, you always feel like you're contributing to society and it's hard to be in a bad mood around the kids.
cons: If you are a non-clinical person, you are at the lowest tier of the totem pole and they will give you as much (usually really low-level) work as you will take on.  Forget reaching your full potential - there's really limited opportunity for us folks.

job_title: Study Coordinator I in Oakland, CA
pros: Amazing people work here. Nursing staff does great work and the researchers I've come across are wonderful. Paid time off is unrivaled (almost 28 days starting off). Patients are the sweetest and your work makes a difference.
cons: Management is disorganized. Flip-flops on expectations, unreasonable deadlines and outright condescending at times. Research staff is SEVERELY understaffed. Training is almost nonexistent as managers don't have time to sit down and train you. It is near impossible to move up the ladder here. It all leads to a ridiculous amount of turnover. Job is really only good for getting your foot in the door with some experience and getting out ASAP.

review_title: Great mission, Great people, good benefits, but management needs to motivate staff better
pros: The doctors, nurses, and all other staff here are excellent and take pride in their job.  Everyone really tries their best to provide the best care for kids.  People are friendly and most departments are fun to work in.  People believe in team work and function cohesively together.  Work life balance is good as long you make it a priority.  It's easy to spend too much time here and many people do.  The salary is somewhat competitive but cannot match the big name competitors for high achievers, therefore aggressive employees tend to leave for greener pastures after several years.  Benefits were awesome 7-9 years ago but have been steadily reduced the last 5 years to match the economy.
cons: Staff cafeteria discount has been reduced from 20% to 15% and then to 10%, while prices have increased 20% over the years.  Cost of food has gotten pretty expensive.  Salaries for non union employees were frozen for several years.  There is not much motivation to work hard for people at the top of their pay scale as salary increases are nominal but you need to be exceptional at your job.  Therefore top performers tend to look elsewhere once they top out.  This is no way to reward long term employees and top talent.  It's very hard to get promoted as there is not much job growth.  Most managers do not seem interested in caring about your career goals.  If you do not care about money and advancement, it would be fine to work here long term...and many people do.  Many departments operate on a skeleton crew so many people are over worked.  There are no performance bonuses or any other incentives for talented staff to strive for.  Many people are making the same amount of money as they were making 10 years ago as a result management reducing the benefits so most people are not ahead of inflation.

pros: The mission is powerful and the organization has good community support. Most people there are very dedicated to helping children and families, however there is a real lack of strategy and leadership.
cons: Weak leadership. A few bad apples can ruin the whole bunch. Some behavior within the organization is sophomoric. sTaff and leadership behave badly, egos abound with few controls. A very weak board of directors. There is no strategic plan. The politics within the organization I would compare to a bad television reality show. Leaders have no idea how to lead people and groups.

pros: Given back to the community and helping the children and providing the services they need.
cons: Upper Management was not willing to work with me regarding my personal circumstances.  I lost my Mother to Lung Cancer while my Manager let me go from the job.  I felt, She could of worked with me and allowed me to have a flexible schedule like the previous Managers did prior to her.

review_title: Awesome mission, awesome people, awesome benefits.
pros: Many people have been working 20+ years here for a reason. The pay is great, and the benefits are better than what you would see in 80% of the companies out there.
cons: Communication about future plans could be better. Most information regarding major changes seems to trickle from employee to employee based on what their managers told them.

pros: Good working relations with a handful of inpatient pharmacy staff (a couple of pharmacists and technicians), the medical residents, patients, janitorial staff and some nurses.
cons: The inpatient pharmacy department is a high-school playground with many bullies/queen-bees.  The management is well aware of the work place bullying going on but refuses to do anything.  Quite simply put the management panders to the bullies.  There are employees in the inpatient pharmacy that are targeted, harassed, bullied, and discriminated against by fellow employees and management rewards them.

pros: Employees are dedicated to provided the best care to children and their families. This is the main reason why employees stay here for such long periods of time.
cons: Most of the management is very much like a high/middle school clique. If you're not one of their favorites or a part of the "in" crowd life will be a living hell. Employee files that should be private are made public in order to bully & cause harm to that employee. If you're not liked they will do everything they can to make you quit including starting rumors to turn others against you. They will smile in your face then slander you behind your back.

pros: Employees love serving the  diverse Oakland community.  If you enjoy working in pediatrics this is a place to see it all.
cons: The hospital is poorly managed.  Don't have the supplies you need to do your job.  Low rate of pay compared to other hospitals in the SF Bay Area.  It is dirty.  Quality of care is compromised for unrealistic budgets.

job_title: Office Assistant in Casablanca, Greater Casablanca
pros: It’s a job with benefits.
cons: Management spreading rumors and gossip that damaged my reputation and lead to me being unable to transfer to another department to escape the abuse. I had an awesome reputation and good annual reviews before transferring to my current department. The middle manager is manipulative and enjoys watching upper management mistreat me based on her lies and rumors. It’s a hostile work environment.

pros: Direct access to leadership and team environment. I've known Dr. Bert Lubin since I was a high school intern and his character and integrity have remained outstanding over many years. That speaks to the character of this employer.
cons: The salaries could be better.

job_title: Clinical Lab Assistant in Oakland, CA
pros:
Lab Specific: 
*A manageable work load, you are overwhelmed with multiple rounds a day. 
*Good supportive management that work with your schedule and are understanding.
*A great team that seem to get along very well. 

Hospital wide: 
* A great crew that really shows that they care about their patients.
cons:
* parking not provided but not a deal breaker
*some spaces are newer & remodeled but have older equipment.

pros: people that work for children's are very friendly and nice, excellent care is provided for the children that are seen at the hospital, because it is a non-profit hospital no sick child is ever turned away.
cons: Unfair management practices,need more management training in how to talk to individuals with respect and not in a degrading tone.

pros: Being a Children's facility, everyones demeanor is positive, helpful and approachful.
cons: At the time that I left, we were merging with UCSF and my pay raise and job title conversion (my title was not appropriately coded with my responsibilities) were placed on hold until further notice.

review_title: Amazing/Supporting Coworkers but higher ups do not support
pros: Amazing healthcare workers who are helping patients and families in need. No matter the speciality, providers support each other on the day to day
cons: The management/corporate part of the hospital are not supportive nor take many ppl's feedbacks into account. They only listen to the MD's. With COVID they had to go on hiring freeze.

pros: Patient population. Many people trying to do the right thing with limited resources/time.
cons: Not enough resources. Poor patient population with many needs that are just not available. Becoming affiliated with UC across the bay should have helped but I can't see it at least not yet.

pros: The pay was very competitive. Management gave a $10 voucher to spend at the cafeteria, which always had tasty healthy options.
cons: Parking was very limited. I had to park in the parking garage, which cost $9.25 per day. However, there was an option to buy in bulk that was a bit cheaper.

pros: Great benefits, great environment to work, all the work felt very rewarding.
cons: In my particular case, mixed shifts made it a little hard on my "internal clock", but there is really nothing negative I can say about CHO.

review_title: Surgery Department: Workplace Bullying and Lack of Integrity
pros: It’s a job that’s all
cons: Management lacks integrity and promotes unqualified employees. They don’t interact with or listen to employees. Hard working people are dumped on and ostracized. No acknowledgement for hard work, they just pile more work onto your plate.

review_title: There for the kids, not the leadership
pros: Seeing the impact you have on low income children, safety net hospital.
cons: Leadership turn over, questionable middle management character, creating limbo departments.

pros: Friendly Security, Good cafeteria food that is not overpriced, coworkers that are great to be around (depends on unit)

pros: Great place if you love children and believe helping children is what you want to do in life.
